newsitem.title: BANGLADESH: Bangladesh leader said target of "outrageous" threats.
newsitem.headline: Bangladesh leader said target of "outrageous" threats.

text.p: The ruling Awami League on Monday accused the opposition Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP) of making outrageous and conspiratorial threats against Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina.
"The threats coming from the BNP leaders are outrageous...and conspiratorial," Awami League's assistant publicity secretary Abdul Mannan said in a statement.
"The BNP leaders threatening the prime minister are playing with fire. It will bring no good results," he said.
Mannan denounced what he called "indecorous" remarks made by BNP leaders at a reception at the Dhaka University on Saturday.
Newspapers quoted BNP leader and former telecommunication minister Tariqul Islam as saying: "The fate of your father awaits you (Hasina).
"Lakhinder (a legend of Hindu mythology) could not survive ...by sleeping in an iron chamber with not a single hole. Your father could not survive, nor shall you."
Hasina's father, Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, Bangladesh's independence leader and first president, was killed in a 1975 army coup along with most of his family.
His death, less than four years after he led Bangladesh to independence from Pakistan in December 1971, was followed by a long spell of rule by generals.

Other BNP officials, including the party's deputy leader in parliament, Badruddoza Chowdhury, also spoke harshly about Hasina and her three-and-a-half month old government. BNP leaders allege Hasina is running a "partisan government" while promising a neutral administration.
They have warned of dire consequences, which political analysts said could mean general strikes and transport shutdowns.
The latest threats against Hasina came as the prime minister sought to put Mujib's accused killers on trial.
A legal advisory committee has drafted a bill proposing repeal of a 1975 ordinance that gave Mujib's assassins indemnity.
Government officials said the draft was expected to be reviewed at a cabinet meeting on Monday before being placed in parliament next month.
Police have arrested three ex-army officers, former information minister Taheruddin Thakur and several others and charged them with Mujib's death.
The investigation started soon after Hasina took over as prime minister following a general election in June that returned her Awami League to power after 21 years.
Police tightenened Hasina's security on her birthday on September 30 after a newspaper reported a plot to kill her.
The daily Ajker Kajog said that "intelligence agents have discovered and foiled a bid to kill Sheikh Hasina. The plot involved some leaders of a major political party who even hired suicide killers".
